{{Infobox Weapon |name= Type 90 75 mm field gun |image=[[File:Type90FG.jpg|300px]] |caption= Type 90 75 mm field gun at the U.S. Army Field Artillery Museum, [[Ft. Sill]], [[Oklahoma|OK]] |origin= [[Empire of Japan]] |type=[[Field gun]] |is_ranged=yes |is_artillery=yes |service=1932-1945 |used_by= [[Imperial Japanese Army]] |wars=[[Second Sino-Japanese War]]
[[Soviet-Japanese Border Wars]]
[[World War II]] |designer= |design_date= |manufacturer= |production_date=1932-1945 |number=786 |variants= |weight= {{convert|1400|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}} (firing)
{{convert|2000|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}} (travel) |length={{convert|5.23|m|ftin|abbr=on}} (firing)
{{convert|3.8712|m|ftin|abbr=on}} (traveling) |part_length= {{convert|2.883|m|ftin|sigfig=1}} L/38.4 |width= {{convert|1.50|m|ftin|abbr=on}} Track
{{convert|1.75|m|ftin|abbr=on}} Maximum |height={{convert|1.65|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |crew= |cartridge={{convert|6.56|kg|lb}} |caliber=75 mm (2.95 in) |action=Manual |rate=2 minutes 15 rpm,
15 minutes 4 rpm
Continuous 100-120 rph |velocity=683 m/s (2,241 ft/s) |range= |max_range={{convert|14960|m|yd}} |feed= |sights=panoramic |breech=horizontal sliding block |recoil=hydro-pneumatic |carriage=split trail |elevation=-8° to +43° |traverse=25° left, 25° right }} The {{nihongo|'''Type 90 75 mm field gun'''|九〇式野砲| Kyūmaru-shiki yahō}} was a [[field gun]] used by the [[Imperial Japanese Army]] during the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]], [[Soviet-Japanese Border Wars]] and [[World War II]]. The Type 90 designation was given to this gun as it was accepted in the year 2590 of the Japanese calendar (1930).War Department TM-E-30-480 ''Handbook on Japanese Military Forces'' September 1944 p 400 It was intended to replace the [[Type 38 75 mm field gun]] in front line combat units, but due to operational and budgetary constraints, the Type 38 continued to be used.Bishop, Chris. ''The Encyclopedia of Weapons of World War II'' ==History and development== Prior to [[World War I]], the Imperial Japanese Army was largely equipped with [[Krupp]] cannons from Germany. After the [[Versailles Treaty]], the Japanese switched to the French [[Schneider et Cie|Schneider]] company, and purchased numerous examples for test and evaluation. With an army rearmament program starting in 1931, a new 75 mm field gun loosely based on the French [[Schneider et Cie]] [[Canon de 85 modèle 1927 Schneider|Canon de 85 mle 1927]] built for GreeceWar Department Special Series No 25 ''Japanese Field Artillery'' October 1944{{sfn|Tomczyk|2005|p=3}}[http://www.historyofwar.org/articles/weapons_type_3_chi_nu.html History of War] was introduced, and labeled the "Type 90".Mayer, S. L. ''The Rise and Fall of Imperial Japan'', pp. 57-59 However, few units were built, and the design never achieved its intended purpose of replacing the [[Type 38 75 mm field gun]]. The Schneider design was very complex and expensive to build, requiring very tight dimensional tolerances which were beyond the limits of Japanese industry to sustain at the time. In particular, the recoil system required a high amount of complex maintenance, which was difficult to sustain in front line combat service.Mayer, S. L. ''The Rise and Fall of Imperial Japan'', p. 59 ==Design== The Type 90 75 mm field gun was unique among Japanese artillery pieces in that it had a [[muzzle brake]]. The carriage was of the split trail type. The Type 90 was built in two version: one with wooden wheels suitable for animal (horse) draft, and another with solid rubber tires and a stronger [[suspension (vehicle)|suspension]] for towing by motor vehicles. The latter weighed {{convert|200|kg|lb}} more.US Department of War. ''TM 30-480, Handbook on Japanese Military Forces'' The Type 90 75 mm field gun was capable of firing [[Shell (projectile)#High-explosive|high-explosive]], [[Armor-piercing shot and shell|armor-piercing]], [[shrapnel shell|shrapnel]], incendiary, [[Shell (projectile)#Smoke|smoke]] and [[Shell (projectile)#Illumination|illumination]] shells. Its range of {{convert|15000|m|yd}} for a weight of {{convert|1400|kg|lb}} compared well with its contemporaries. ==Combat record== The Type 90 75 mm field gun was issued primarily to units based in [[Manchukuo]], and was rarely deployed to the [[Pacific War|Pacific theatre of operations]]. Its initial use in combat was against the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[Red Army]] at the [[Nomonhan Incident|Battle of Nomonhan]]. When deployed later against [[Allies of World War II|Allied forces]], it was often used as an [[anti-tank gun]], as its high speed shells were effective against armored vehicles.MacLean, Donald B. ''Japanese Artillery: Weapons and Tactics'' It was also used at the [[Philippines Campaign (1944–45)|Battle of the Philippines]], [[Battle of Iwo Jima]] and [[Battle of Okinawa]], often deployed together with armored units. The Type 90 continued to be used as field artillery until the [[surrender of Japan]].[http://www3.plala.or.jp/takihome/90-75.htm Taki's Imperial Japanese Army: "Type 90 75mm Field Gun"] ==Variants== The Type 90 formed the basis for the [[Type 3 75 mm tank gun]] used in the [[Type 3 Chi-Nu]] medium [[tank]].{{sfn|Tomczyk|2005|p=3}} ==References== ===Notes=== {{reflist}} ===Bibliography=== * Bishop, Chris (eds). ''The Encyclopedia of Weapons of World War II'', Barnes & Nobel, 1998, ISBN 0-7607-1022-8 * McLean, Donald B. ''Japanese Artillery: Weapons and Tactics'', Wickenburg, Ariz. Normount Technical Publications, 1973, ISBN 0-87947-157-3 * Mayer, S. L. ''The Rise and Fall of Imperial Japan'', The Military Press, 1984, ISBN 0-517-42313-8 *{{cite book | last = Tomczyk | first = Andrzej | year = 2005 | title = Japanese Armor Vol. 4 | publisher = AJ Press | location = | isbn = 978-8372371676 | ref = harv }} * US Department of War Special Series No 25 '' Japanese Field Artillery'' October 1944 * US Department of War. ''TM 30-480, Handbook on Japanese Military Forces'', Louisiana State University Press, 1994, ISBN 0-8071-2013-8 ==Further reading== * Chamberlain, Peter and Gander, Terry. ''Light and Medium Field Artillery''. Macdonald and Jane's, 1975, ISBN 0-356-08215-6 * Chant, Chris. ''Artillery of World War II'', Zenith Press, 2001, ISBN 0-7603-1172-2 ==External links== * [http://www3.plala.or.jp/takihome/90-75.htm Type 90 on Taki's Imperial Japanese Army page] * [http://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/Japan/IJA/HB/HB-9.html#III U.S. Technical Manual TM-E 30-480] {{Commons category|Type 90 75 mm Field Gun}} {{Imperial Japanese Army artillery}} [[Category:World War II field artillery]] [[Category:World War II artillery of Japan|9]] [[Category:75 mm artillery]] [[Category:Schneider Electric]]
